content.text:
As an API contributor
I want to be able to create COMPANY nodes
So I can fill gaps in the database
A COMPANY node is successfully created when requested with valid data. The required data structure is specified in parent (epic) ticket MCA-201. -> Status Code `201`
A successful request returns the created node with all specified properties.
Properties are returned, even when they are empty (optional fields). They are returned with value `null`.
Unknown properties are ignored. They are not processed. They do not produce any info, warning or error messages for the user. -> Status Code `201`
Read-only properties (`id`, `created_at`, `updated_at`) are ignored. They are not processed. They do not produce any info, warning or error messages for the user. -> Status Code `201`
Requests with invalid data are rejected. Cases for invalid data include: missing mandatory fields, syntax errors, wrong data types or wrong data structure. -> Status Code `400`

issuetype.description: Eine Sammlung ähnlicher Bugs, Stories und Tasks.
issuetype.name: Epic

content.text: When requesting a list of NODEs (e.g. Images)
I want to fetch them in slices (instead of the whole collection at once)
So I don't have to wait for and parse a giant response object

The user should be able to restrict the amount of nodes that are returned in a collection. This is for performance reasons (loading thousands of nodes takes some time) and to make it easier for the user to work on the response objects. When requesting a collection the user should be provided with enough meta information to create an informed request (e.g. how many pages are there in total and how big are they).
can be attached to every “get all nodes of node type” request, e.g.
items of the original collection (page size is fixed).
The last page returns the remaining items (between
Each page contains a different subset of the original collection.
When a valid page number was provided then the response returns with code
Even when the collection is empty (which should only happen in edge cases).
is always a valid page number, no matter how large the collection is.
and negative page numbers lead to a
Any value that is not a number (e.g.
When a page is requested that is out-of-range then a
error is returned (e.g. page 10 is requested, but there are only 8).
The response returns additional meta data:
The meta data is always returned, even when no pagination was requested.
The data structure of the returned items in the collection stays untouched.
The page size is static for now. Making it configurable comes later.
The collections are not explicitly sorted. The database decides the order. This might lead to duplicates across multiple pages. This will be tackled in a different ticket.
What happens when providing the page parameter multiple times? Depends on how Express.js handles this case. TBD.
Collisions between meta information and collection data is possible, e.g. field “pages” in node type “Book”. Will be tackled in a separate ticket.
